course.subject: SOSC
course.name: Educational Psychology
course.description: Educational Psychology relates the fields of psychology and education with one another, examining the theories, research methods, and research findings on human development, learning, and instruction. Topics covered include cognitive, language, and literacy development; social, moral, and emotional development; effective teaching and learning strategies; individual differences in learning; assessment of learning; and educational issues currently relevant in the Hong Kong society. This course is appropriate for those who are interested in a career in teaching, but also for those who are interested in understanding how development occurs across the lifespan and becoming more efficient learners, both inside and outside of the classroom.
course.prerequisites: SOSC 1960 OR SOSC 1980

reviews.author: tchuuuuuu
reviews.comment_content:
Introduction to Dewey, Montessori, Piaget, Vygotsky
Cognitive and language development
Cognitive impact of bilingualism
Social, moral, & emotional development
Understanding and addressing bullying
Cognitive theories of learning
Memory and meaning-making
Behavioral theories of learning
Reinforcement & punishment in education
-------------------------------------------------
The effective lesson
Constructivist approaches to instruction
Standardized testing and assessments
Grouping and differentiation
Learners with exceptionalities
Teaching children with ASD (autism)
Student diversity
Implementing multicultural education

The content is interesting and some might differ from your general knowledge. It is really a nice course for a better educator and even for everyone. Standing on the students/children's side and giving what they really need in terms of psychological aspect is really important for their growth.

reviews.comment_workload:
Really low workload.
You can easily get full marks in reading response papers and activities (40%).
In this semester, the quizzes contain only MC questions in an open-book format. Some questions are detailed, try to really understand all the experiments and pay attention to the in-class videos. Since it was a mixed-mode course, it might differ from the structure for the coming f2f semester.
Designing an 80minute course project might be the only work, but it is really fun to come up with a whole new lesson with the rationale back up by the course materials by yourself.
